channel.title: This won't run?

item.title: This won't run?
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“kingman002, post:7, topic:451704”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=554592.msg4062209#msg4062209 date=1343521289]
If you have problems with user input you could use this: http://pastie.org/private/inwa8lqbjzmhbp0cdnivw
[/quote]
It’s a nice class to have, but it’s not what I’m looking for. I’ll keep it handy if I ever use it.

So I’m just going to make new scanners for every type there is a user input with typing. That’s the only way I can think of so this thing I’m making isn’t glitched (by using the Utils class.)

Edit: Question. What can I do to make this work:

So what can I add if the string youranswer has any of the things in realanswer, it returns true.

if(youranswer.equals(realanswer)) { System.out.println("Boss: Good. On to the first round of questions."); } else { System.out.println("Boss: You don't want to play? Too bad. You're playing.\nNow the first round of questions."); }
It returns false every time.

I just want to learn :o[/quote]

Arrays start at 0, so if you want to get the first string you need to do realanswer[0]; and so on, but if your wanting something random pulled out of it you could make a Random object from java.util, and do something like this.

Read full topic

item.title: This won't run?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[code]
boolean found = false;
for(String s : realanswer) {
if(youranswer.equals(s)) {
found = true;
break;
}
}

if(found) {
System.out.println(“Good”);
} else {
System.out.println(“Too bad”);
}[/code]

Something like that. Requires you to loop through every possible answer and see if they match

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @kingman002 kingman002
item.description:
@kingman002 wrote:

Whackatre:

If you have problems with user input you could use this: http://pastie.org/private/inwa8lqbjzmhbp0cdnivw

It’s a nice class to have, but it’s not what I’m looking for. I’ll keep it handy if I ever use it.

So I’m just going to make new scanners for every type there is a user input with typing. That’s the only way I can think of so this thing I’m making isn’t glitched (by using the Utils class.)

Edit: Question. What can I do to make this work:

So what can I add if the string youranswer has any of the things in realanswer, it returns true.

if(youranswer.equals(realanswer)) { System.out.println("Boss: Good. On to the first round of questions."); } else { System.out.println("Boss: You don't want to play? Too bad. You're playing.\nNow the first round of questions."); }
It returns false every time.

I just want to learn :o

item.title: This won't run?
item.dc:creator: @kingman002 kingman002
item.description:
@kingman002 wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:2, topic:451704”] public static Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in); public static String youranswer = s.nextLine(); public static String youranswer2 = s.nextLine();

Is called when the class is loaded, which happens to be before the JVM resumes execution of main(String[]). It will hang until the scanner receives two valid “lines”[/quote]
So what can I do then?

[quote=“Scape-JAVA, post:3, topic:451704”] public static void twosec() { try { Thread.sleep(2000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void fivesec() { try { Thread.sleep(5000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void sec() { try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void threesec() { try { Thread.sleep(3000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void foursec() { try { Thread.sleep(4000); } catch(Exception e) {} } }

err, I fail to see the necessity.[/quote]
You could have just said what Whackatre said.

Edit: Fixed. Thanks. But It doesn’t let me type for this part (updated code in main post), but it does if I make another scanner.

System.out.println("Hmm.... "); youranswer2 = s.nextLine();

Read full topic

@Scape-JAVA wrote:

public static void twosec() { try { Thread.sleep(2000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void fivesec() { try { Thread.sleep(5000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void sec() { try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void threesec() { try { Thread.sleep(3000); } catch(Exception e) {} } public static void foursec() { try { Thread.sleep(4000); } catch(Exception e) {} } }

err, I fail to see the necessity.

item.title: This won't run?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

public static Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in); public static String youranswer = s.nextLine(); public static String youranswer2 = s.nextLine();

Is called when the class is loaded, which happens to be before the JVM resumes execution of main(String[]). It will hang until the scanner receives two valid “lines”

Read full topic

item.title: This won't run?
item.dc:creator: @kingman002 kingman002
item.description:
@kingman002 wrote:

Fixed. Kind of, read all the posts, please.

[code=java]import java.util.Scanner;
/*
*@author kingman002
*/
public class okay {

public static Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);
public static String youranswer;
public static String youranswer2;
public static String realanswer = "alright";
public static String realanswer2 = "sure";
public static int money;

public static void main(String[] args) {
	System.out.println("Yep. Okay");
	twosec();
	System.out.println("... ....1");
	fivesec();
	System.out.println("...........2");
	foursec();
	System.out.println("............3");
	threesec();
	System.out.println("..............4");
	twosec();
	System.out.println("............5");
	sec();
	System.out.print("Opinion: a ");
	youranswer = s.nextLine();
	
	if(youranswer.equals(realanswer)) {
		System.out.println("..................6");
	} else {
		System.out.println("..................7");
	}
	twosec();
	System.out.println(".......................8");
	twosec();
	System.out.println("........................9");
	threesec();
	System.out.println("..............10");
	threesec();
	System.out.println(".................11");
	threesec();
	System.out.println("...........12\n...............13");
	fivesec();
	System.out.println("..........................14");
	sec();
	System.out.println("Options:\n Yes!....15 \n If I say no, then I'll lose.....16\n");
	System.out.print("Choice: ");
	
	int a = s.nextInt();
	
	switch(a){
	case 1:
		System.out.println("Nice...........17");
		break;
	case 2: System.out.println("The game.........18");
		break;
	}
	twosec();
	System.out.println("...........19");
	sec();
	System.out.println("............20");
	sec();
	System.out.println("Hmm.... ");
	youranswer2 = s.nextLine();
	
	if(youranswer2.equals(realanswer2)) {
		money += 5;
		System.out.println("Here's $5!");
	}
	twosec();
	System.out.println("You have completed wave 1... You have a total of $" +money+ ".");
}


public static void twosec() {
try {
	Thread.sleep(2000);
} catch(Exception e) {}
}
public static void fivesec() {
	try {
		Thread.sleep(5000);
	} catch(Exception e) {}
}
public static void sec() {
	try {
		Thread.sleep(1000);
	} catch(Exception e) {}
	}
public static void threesec() {
		try {
			Thread.sleep(3000);
		} catch(Exception e) {}
		}
public static void foursec() {
	try {
		Thread.sleep(4000);
	} catch(Exception e) {}
	}

}
[/code]
Fixed. kind of. Read all posts
